title.narrative: POWER: Promoting Opportunities for Women's Empowerment and Rights (Women's Rights to Sustainable Livelihoods 2)

description.narrative: The POWER project is a five year initiative (2016-2020). Its overall objective is to increase the income, and the ability to control this income, of 19,501 rural women in Bangladesh, Ghana and Rwanda. POWER was also implemented in Pakistan between 2016 - 2018. The targets have been updated following the closure of the Pakistan office; previous targets can be found on the Original logframe and the actual numbers achieved by ActionAid Pakistan can be found on the POWER 2018 Annual Report.

organisation.narrative: ActionAid UK - Programme Quality Assurance Team

recipient-country.narrative: The project was implemented in Pakistan only from 2016-2018.

sector.narrative: Specific Objective: 21,000 women in Ghana, Rwanda, Bangladesh and Pakistan have increased income and ability to control their income, through practicing CRSA, accessing markets and reducing,recognising and redistributing unpaid care work

policy-marker.narrative: Long Term Objective: To contribute to the increased economic empowerment of women in Ghana, Rwanda, Bangladesh and Pakistan
To contribute to the increased economic empowerment of women in Ghana, Rwanda, Bangladesh and Pakistan

Project Theory of Change
3. By the end of 2020, 19,501 rural women have more secure and sustainable access to markets and productive resources leading to increased income
3.c Percentage of sampled women who report an increase in their income by the end of the project

description.narrative: This will only be reported at the end of the project

title.narrative: 3.b Percentage of women surveyed who report improved yields as a result of using Climate Resilient Sustainable Agriculture techniques and agricultural inputs by the end of the project

description.narrative: This will only be reported at the end of the project

title.narrative: 3.a Percentage of women report increased, more regular access to markets by the end of the project

description.narrative: This will only be reported at the end of the project

title.narrative: 2. By the end of 2020 Women's Unpaid Care Work (UCW) is more highly valued within households, communities and government, more evenly distributed within households and hours spent by women on UCW is reduced, resulting in more free time for women to engage in social, economic and political activities
2.c Percentage reduction in the amount of time women spend on unpaid care work between 2016 and 2019

description.narrative: This will only be reported at the end of the project

title.narrative: 2.b Percentage of sampled target households where women report a positive redistribution of time spent on UCW by the end of the project

description.narrative: This will only be reported at the end of the project

title.narrative: 2.d Percentage of sampled women who report having more time to spend on social, economic or political activities by the end of the project

description.narrative: This will only be reported at the end of the project

title.narrative: 2.a Percentage of duty-bearers, men and women sampled from target communities reporting positive attitudes towards addressing unpaid care work by the end of the project

description.narrative: This will only be reported at the end of the project

title.narrative: 4. Greater visibility of intersections of Climate Resilient Sustainable Agriculture, women's Unpaid Care Work and women's economic participation leads to changes in policy and practice by sub-national, national, regional and international stakeholders by 2020
4.a Percentage of local and national duty bearers surveyed who agree that greater support and investment is needed to reduce UCW by the end of the project

description.narrative: This will only be reported at the end of the project

title.narrative: 4.b Number of new or revised strategy or policy documents from national, regional or international bodies or bi-lateral donors that address gender inequality facing rural women including disproportionate burden of unpaid care work and its impact on sustainable farming techniques and women�s economic empowerment

description.narrative: This will only be reported at the end of the project

title.narrative: 4.c Increase in national policy support for interventions that reduces women�s unpaid care work as assessed by key external experts in each country, by the end of the project

description.narrative: This will only be reported at the end of the project

title.narrative: 3.1 14,000 (Ghana 3000, Rwanda 6000, Bangladesh 5000) rural women are trained on market access, processing, packaging and marketing methodologies by 2020
3.1.a Number of women trained on business skills, markets and processing by the end of the project
3.1.b Number of women's groups keeping accurate financial records to manage their income and expenditure
3.1.c Percentage of women with improved knowledge of how to access markets and how to get current market information by the end of the project
1. By the end of 2020 19,501 rural women are organised and are able to demand their rights as farmers and carers and have greater influence in their households and communities
1.c Percentage of women who report having greater control over resources in their households by the end of the project

description.narrative: This will only be reported at the end of the project

title.narrative: 1.d Percentage of target communities in each country in which a majority of sampled women report greater presence of women on community structures by the end of the project

description.narrative: This will only be reported at the end of the project

title.narrative: 1.b Percentage of targeted women who report increased skills and confidence in demanding their rights and reporting cases of violence by the end of the project

description.narrative: This will only be reported at the end of the project

title.narrative: 1.a 19,501 women are organised in groups and actively participating in group activities by the end of the project
1.2 19,501 (6,000 Ghana, 7,350 Rwanda, 6,151 Bangladesh) rural women are trained about their rights and how to report and respond to cases of Violence Against Women (VAW) by December 2020
1.2.a Number of women trained about their rights and VAW reporting mechanisms by the end of 2020
1.2.b Percentage of women trained who have improved knowledge of rights by the end of the training round
1.2.c Percentage of women trained have correct knowledge of how to report incidences of VAW and available support services (legal, health etc.) by the end of each training round
1.3 683 women's groups (200 Ghana, 245 Rwanda, 238 Bangladesh) trained in women's leadership and local decision-making community structures are sensitised to women's participation by 2020
1.3.a Number of women trained on women's leadership in each country by the end of 2018
1.3.c Percentage of women regularly participating in community structures by the end of the project
1.3.b Percentage of women leaders trained who report having greater skills and self-confidence to participate in community structures by the end of 2018
2.2 19,501 women (6,000 Ghana, 7,350 Rwanda, 6,151 Bangladesh) and 5,200 men and boys have improved awareness of the time women spend on UCW by 2020
2.2.a Number of women and men who have completed a time diary at least once as part of sensitisation activities by the end of the project
2.2.b Number of dialogue meetings where evidence from time diaries is shared and comparisons between men and women's discussed by the end of the project
2.2.c Number of local awareness raising initiatives carried out relating to women's UCW by the end of the project

4.2 16 national and regional evidence documents are produced on intersections of unpaid care work and climate resilient sustainable agriculture to improve evidence base of successful interventions to remove barriers to women's economic participation

4.2.2. Number of evidence documents used, presented and shared by ActionAid in internal platforms, regional and international meetings which reflect the intersections of unpaid care work, agroecology to improve learning on successful interventions to remove barriers to women’s economic participation
4.2.a Number of evidence documents researched and produced by the end of the project
1.1 683 women's groups (200 Ghana, 245 Rwanda, 238 Bangladesh) are set up and/or strengthened in their community by December 2016
1.1.c Percentage of partner staff, community mobilisers and Reflect facilitators with improved knowledge of HRBA and Reflect methodologies by the end of 2016
1.1.a Number of groups meeting at least once per month
1.1.b Number of facilitators and staff trained on the HRBA and REFLECT methodologies by the end of 2016
2.1 683 women's groups (200 Ghana, 245 Rwanda, 238 Bangladesh) are represented in local level government meetings on budgetary allocation and in kind support to address Unpaid Care Work (UCW) by 2020
2.1.c Number of documented cases whereby local level government take positive action providing support (budgetary or in-kind) to address women's UCW by the end of the project
2.1.a Number of groups trained on participatory budget monitoring and tracking by the end of year 2020
2.1.b Number of sensitisation / advocacy meetings where women present UCW data to duty-bearers and the need for budgetary / in-kind support by the end of the project
3.2 683 women's groups provided with and supported to access productive resources by 2020
3.2.b Number of women accessing seeds through seed banks or direct inputs by the end of the project
3.2.c Percentage of women reporting improved service provision from agricultural extension workers by the end of the project
3.2.a Number of women's groups trained and supported to set up and manage functioning saving schemes to increase their access to finance by the end of the project
4.3 7 Policy briefs on Unpaid Care Work (UCW) and women's economic empowerment are produced and shared by 2020
4.3.b Number of copies of policy briefs shared or downloaded by the end of the project
4.3.a Number of policy briefs on UCW and women's economic empowerment produced by the end of the project

2.3 Interventions aimed at reducing unpaid care work (child care initiatives, water harvesting technologies, energy saving cooking stoves, solar cookers, fodder trees, cutters and woodlots) are tested and scaled up in communities and evidence documented by 2020

2.3.a Percentage of women trained on implementing and managing time saving household or community interventions have the skills and confidence to share their training with others, by the end of each training round
2.3.b Percentage of female users report satisfaction and time savings with interventions that they use
2.3.c Number of types of time saving interventions for which evidence of their success is documented by the end of the project

4.1 683 women's groups are linked to alliances, networks and coalitions at local, regional and national level and develop and implement a minimum of one joint advocacy plan to demand their rights regards, violence against women, unpaid care work, market access and access to sustainable agriculture resources
4.1.c Percentage of women (19.501) attend advocacy meetings and national advocacy moments
4.1.a Percentage of women trained who report having greater confidence to use the advocacy skills they've learnt, by the end of each round of training
4.1.b Percentage of women's groups linked to networks and alliances per country that implement their advocacy plans by the end of the project
4.4 22 advocacy initiatives are held regarding Unpaid Care Work (UCW) and women's economic empowerment with regional African and Asian platforms and international platforms
4.4.a Number of meetings / conferences held to discuss and promote addressing UCW as a barrier to women's economic participation by the end of the project
4.4.b Percentage of duty-bearers and decision makers who attend meetings who provide positive feedback to ActionAid about the content and usefulness of meetings
3.3 683 women's groups practice and understand climate resilient sustainable agricultural techniques (CRSA) by 2020
3.3.b Number of women's groups that have initiated or supported members to initiate CRSA techniques by the end of the project
3.3.c Percentage of women small holder farmers provide positive feedback on their experiences of using CRSA techniques by the end of the project
3.3.a Percentage of sampled rural women trained with improved knowledge of CRSA principles and techniques by the end of the project
